body: Thanks for reporting it, @xbif. We'll look into it.
Hey, is this something I could work on as a newcomer?

@JanUrb thanks for the offer, the recursive comparison is a bit tricky so I would not recommend it as a first issue to work on.
We usually label issues that newcomers can pick with "Good first issue", have a look if there is one you'd like to contribute

issue.title: Fix usingRecursiveComparison with usingOverriddenEquals ignores equalâ€¦

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
Please do not merge as it is in progress

Fix #2479

#### Check List:
* Fixes #2479
* Unit tests : YES
* Javadoc with a code example (on API only) : NO
* PR meets the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/assertj/assertj-core/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md)

Following the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/assertj/assertj-core/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) will make it easier for us to review and accept your PR.

body:
I'm sorry.
I was also starting to work.
I made it in the draft version, but I had some concerns, so let me ask you a question.

@joel-costigliola 
I have confirmed that the commit "1f8a43e6fa" has been changed so that the equals method is not used in the case of root object.
Is there anything wrong with my fix?

@JanUrb 
Once the above problem is resolved, you can use my pull request to change it.
In that case I will close my pull request.

thank you.
thanks for the analysis and the test case @JanUrb! :)

So it looks like the issue only occurs when comparing root object and `usingOverriddenEquals`, although this is a bug there is no point of using the recursive comparison combined with `usingOverriddenEquals` on the root object, better in this case to simply use `isEqualTo` which will perform the same assertion but will give a better error message (one that IDE can show visual diff):
```java
assertThat(actual).isEqualTo(expected);
```

Thank you for letting me know.
You're right.
I will close the pull request.

Leave it open @uc4w6c, I'm looking at it and it might be that we don't need `isRootObject` anymore (which you have removed in your PR). I'll see if I can confirm that and if I do I'll integrate your PR and you'll get the credit for fixing this one :) (usually I get the PR code, play with it, refactor it if needed, squash all commits but keep the original PR author)
